refnamediv.refpurpose: A polymorphic type that can hold values of any other type

refsynopsisdiv.title: Synopsis

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The GValue structure is basically a variable container that consists of a type identifier and a specific value of that type. The type identifier within a GValue structure always determines the type of the associated value. To create a undefined GValue structure, simply create a zero-filled GValue structure. To initialize the GValue, use the g_value_init() function. A GValue cannot be used until it is initialized. The basic type operations (such as freeing and copying) are determined by the GTypeValueTable associated with the type ID stored in the GValue. Other GValue operations (such as converting values between types) are provided by this interface.

refsect2.title: G_VALUE_HOLDS()
refsect2.para: Returns TRUE if value holds (or contains) a value of type. This macro will also check for value != NULL and issue a warning if the check fails.

refsect2.title: G_VALUE_TYPE()
refsect2.para: Returns the type identifier of value.

refsect2.title: G_VALUE_TYPE_NAME()
refsect2.para: Returns the type name of value.

refsect2.title: G_TYPE_IS_VALUE()
refsect2.para: Return whether the passed in type ID can be used for g_value_init(). That is, this macro checks whether this type provides an implementation of the GTypeValueTable functions required for a type to create a GValue of.

listitem.simpara: Whether type is suitable as a GValue type.

refsect2.title: G_TYPE_IS_VALUE_ABSTRACT()
refsect2.para: Returns TRUE if type is an abstract value type. An abstract value type introduces a value table, but can't be used for g_value_init() and is normally used as an abstract base type for derived value types.

refsect2.title: G_IS_VALUE()
refsect2.para: Returns TRUE if value is a valid and initialized GValue structure.

refsect2.title: struct GValue
refsect2.para: An opaque structure used to hold different types of values. The data within the structure has protected scope: it is accessible only to functions within a GTypeValueTable structure, or implementations of the g_value_*() API. That is, code portions which implement new fundamental types. GValue users can not make any assumptions about how data is stored within the 2 element GValue.data[] union, and the g_type member should only be accessed through the G_VALUE_TYPE() macro.

refsect2.title: G_TYPE_VALUE
refsect2.para: Returns the type ID of the "GValue" type which is a boxed type, used to pass around pointers to GValues.

refsect2.title: G_TYPE_VALUE_ARRAY
refsect2.para: Returns the type ID of the "GValueArray" type which is a boxed type, used to pass around pointers to GValueArrays.

refsect2.title: g_value_init ()
refsect2.para: Initializes value with the default value of type.

listitem.simpara: Type the GValue should hold values of.

refsect2.title: g_value_copy ()
refsect2.para: Copies the value of src_value into dest_value.

listitem.simpara: An initialized GValue structure of the same type as src_value.

refsect2.title: g_value_reset ()
refsect2.para: Clears the current value in value and resets it to the default value (as if the value had just been initialized).

refsect2.title: g_value_unset ()
refsect2.para: Clears the current value in value and "unsets" the type, this releases all resources associated with this GValue. An unset value is the same as an uninitialized (zero-filled) GValue structure.

refsect2.title: g_value_fits_pointer ()
refsect2.para: Determines if value will fit inside the size of a pointer value. This is an internal function introduced mainly for C marshallers.

listitem.simpara: TRUE if value will fit inside a pointer value.

refsect2.title: g_value_peek_pointer ()
refsect2.para: Return the value contents as pointer. This function asserts that g_value_fits_pointer() returned TRUE for the passed in value. This is an internal function introduced mainly for C marshallers.

listitem.simpara: TRUE if value will fit inside a pointer value.

refsect2.title: g_value_type_compatible ()
refsect2.para: Returns whether a GValue of type src_type can be copied into a GValue of type dest_type.

listitem.simpara: TRUE if g_value_copy() is possible with src_type and dest_type.

refsect2.title: g_value_type_transformable ()
refsect2.para: Check whether g_value_transform() is able to transform values of type src_type into values of type dest_type.

listitem.simpara: TRUE if the transformation is possible, FALSE otherwise.

refsect2.title: g_value_transform ()
refsect2.para: Tries to cast the contents of src_value into a type apropriate to store in dest_value, e.g. to transform a G_TYPE_INT value into a G_TYPE_FLOAT value. Performing transformations between value types might incour precision lossage. Especially transformations into strings might reveal seemingly arbitrary results and shouldn't be relied upon for production code (such as rcfile value or object property serialization).

listitem.simpara: Whether a transformation rule was found and could be applied. Upon failing transformations, dest_value is left untouched.

refsect2.title: GValueTransform ()
refsect2.para: The type of value transformation functions which can be registered with g_value_register_transform_func().

refsect2.title: g_value_register_transform_func ()
refsect2.para: Registers a value transformation function for use in g_value_transform(). A previously registered transformation function for src_type and dest_type will be replaced.

listitem.simpara: a function which transforms values of type src_type into value of type dest_type

refsect2.title: g_strdup_value_contents ()
refsect2.para: Return a newly allocated string, which describes the contents of a GValue. The main purpose of this function is to describe GValue contents for debugging output, the way in which the contents are described may change between different GLib versions.

listitem.simpara: GValue which contents are to be described.

refsect1.title: See Also
refsect1.para: The fundamental types which all support GValue operations and thus can be used as a type initializer for g_value_init() are defined by a separate interface. See the Standard Values API for details.
